newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER SHOWCASE-BRAZILIAN FRIENDS MEET IN BARCA-REAL CLASH.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER SHOWCASE-BRAZILIAN FRIENDS MEET IN BARCA-REAL CLASH.

text.p: In a season in which Brazilians have grabbed centre-stage in the cosmpolitan Spanish league, no stars have shone greater than those of Barcelona striker Ronaldo and Real Madrid defender Roberto Carlos.
But even the close friendship that has grown up between the two players looks likely to be stretched by the tension surrounding Saturday's eagerly-awaited top of the table clash.
"Real Madrid, you shouldn't feel champions yet," said a defiant Ronaldo.
"I really want to win the game because we have still got many possibilities of taking the championship."

Ronaldo's 31 goals already this season have made him a firm candidate to win the Golden Boot for scorers in European leagues, and he still has a good chance of equalling Hugo Sanchez's record 38 goals in the Spanish league.
The 107 goals scored by Sanchez and his Real teammates in 1989-90 are also a record within Barcelona's reach.
But neither record would be much compensation for a Barcelona team that has lacked the consistency of their arch-rivals.
For much of the early part of the season the individual brilliance of Ronaldo papered over the cracks in the Barcelona system.
In one case he wriggled through the Valencia defence for a brilliant hat-trick, and Bobby Robson's side grabbed a 3-2 victory in a game in which they deserved no more than a point.
And it hasn't just been Ronaldo's goals that have impressed Spanish fans.
Ronaldo's refusal to go down when challenged -- which has contrasted with the widely-criticised 'swimming pool' style of Real striker Predrag Mijatovic -- has won plaudits from all sides.
Ronaldo's ever-smiling friend Roberto Carlos is just as admired for his good temparament.

Roberto Carlos' arrival in Spain was not as dramatic as that of his Brazilian international teammate, but within three games he was a well-known figure after crashing home a superb 30-metre equaliser against Real Betis.

The swirling free-kicks quickly became an integral part of Real's offensive armoury, leaving international set-piece specialists like Fernando Hierro, Predrag Mijatovic and Davor Suker without a significant share of Real's goal tally.
And an exceptional turn-of-speed have made Roberto Carlos a constant menace down the wing,
The arrival of fellow full-back Christian Panucci has also given Roberto Carlos an ideal target man at corners and free-kicks from the wings.
But even an enviably well-rounded player like Roberto Carlos may find the pressure in the Camp Nou difficult.
Earlier in the season he called the Barcelona fans the "most racist in Spain".
Shortly afterwards a racial insult was scratched onto his car, leading Roberto Carlos to suggest that he may leave Spain.
The incident seems to have been forgotten, and Roberto Carlos promises to ignore the traditionally vociferous Barcelona fans.
"I will turn a deaf ear to what they say to me from the stands," he said "We must be relaxed and concentrated."
But Ronaldo is sure that the pressure is bound to play in favour of the home side.
"The fans always help and the Camp Nou should be tougher than ever," he said.
